BALTIMORE

Athletes of Argentina, Uruguay
and Chile are training enthusiastically for the South American
Olympic Championship games, to
be held at Santiago, Chile, in the
latter part of April. The Uruguayan team has already been
chosen, and the Argentine national championships, from which
that country's representatives are
picked, were held on April 4. This
is the second South American
Olympiad, last year's being held
at Montevideo, and the program is
much the same as that of the
Olympic Games to be held at Antwerp.

Columbia.

Intercollegiate athletics, in the
year of 1918-1919, cost Columbia
the sum of $7,798.55, this being
the deficit between the receipts
and expenditures when balanced,
according to a report by the athletic association. The income from
alumni, faculty and students' athletic fees was only slightly more
than $8,100 and the total expenses
nearly $16,000. Track, baseball
and crew were the heaviest losers,
while football under the S. A. T.
C. regime was the only sport to
show a credit. The minor sports
helped to make up the deficit.
New Penn Club in New York.

The New York Alumni of Penn
have just purchased a nine-story
building at 11 to 17 East 45th
street for a club. This site, just
off Fifth Avenue, is one of the
finest in the clubhouse district,
and the building itself, formerly
considered one of the best apartment houses in the city, is excellently suited for the purpose of
the Club, containing every improvement, in addition to smoking, lounging and billiard rooms.

LA R G E.

In the recent dual meet with
Harvard, a new world's record for
the 200-yard swimming relay race
was established by the Yale swimming team, which covered the distance in the remarkable time of
1 minute, and 39 and 4-5 seconds.
The team won the meet by the
score of 48 to 5, and clipped a
second from the previous record
of 1 minute, and 40 and 4-5 seconds. The new record was established by the team which created
the former record on February 13,
composed of the following men:
J. M. Hincks,of Bridgeport,Conn.;
L. Thurston, of Honolulu; E. Binney, of Sound Beach, Conn., and
R. F. Solly, of New York City.
The girls at Milwaukee Normal
School are taking an active interest in the science of "Leap-Year
Proposals." They have leaped to
the leap - year opportunity en
masse, and their study of "how
to pop" may change the course of
many lives. Boys, beware!

HOWARD AND LEXINGTON

Collegiate Swimming Association Holds
Second Meeting at Hopkins' Club.

The Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association, which was organized recently, held its second
meeting on April 17, at the Hopkins Club. The meeting was attended by J. C. Riley, of Rutgers;
Farington, of Lehigh, and B. Russell Murphy, Theodore Gould and
D. Rowland, of Hopkins. At
present, only four colleges—Lehigh, Rutgers, Catholic University
and Johns Hopkins—have ratified
the constitution. It is expected,
however, that Stevens, Swarthmore and Haverford will join the
association before the end of the
week.
At the meeting of April 17, the
by-laws were drawn up, modeled
after those of the Inter-Collegiate
Swimming Association. The officers of the association and executive committee were elected. The
officers are: J. C. Riley, of Rutgers, president; Charles V. Moran, of Catholic University, vicepresident; Theodore Gould, of
Hopkins, secretary; Farington, of
Lehigh, treasurer. The executive
committee is composed of the four
men just mentioned and Prof. H.
R. Reiter, of Lehigh; B. Russell
Murphy, of Hopkins; Mehrhoff, of
Rutgers, and Bruhuer, of Catholic
University. Tentative plans have
been made for the first swimming
meet, to take place in one of the
eastern cities next fall.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 20, 1920.

IJAS. SCHOULER LECTURESHIP1
In March, 1908, Dr. James
Schouler, of Boston, who had lectured in this University annually
since 1891, announced his purpose
to found a permanent lectureship
in the University, to be known as
"The James Schouler Lectureship
in History and Political Science."
The -donor expressed that wish
that "such lectures be given annually, if possible, . . . and that
persons of promise or prominence
be selected to lecture, who are
capable of interesting, as well as
instructing, an audience."
The ninth course on the Schouler Foundation will be delivered
by Paul Samuel Reinsch, Ph. D.,
LL. D., scholar and diplomat,
sometime United States Minister
to China, who will give five lectures on "The Development of Nationalism and Representative Government in China."
The lectures will be given in the
hall of the Civil Engineering
Building at Homewood, beginning
Tuesday, April 20, 1920, at 4.15
o'clock. Entrance to the grounds
at Charles and Thirty-second
streets.

BALTIMORE

Athletes of Argentina, Uruguay
and Chile are training enthusiastically for the South American
Olympic Championship games, to
be held at Santiago, Chile, in the
latter part of April. The Uruguayan team has already been
chosen, and the Argentine national championships, from which
that country's representatives are
picked, were held on April 4. This
is the second South American
Olympiad, last year's being held
at Montevideo, and the program is
much the same as that of the
Olympic Games to be held at Antwerp.

Columbia.

Intercollegiate athletics, in the
year of 1918-1919, cost Columbia
the sum of $7,798.55, this being
the deficit between the receipts
and expenditures when balanced,
according to a report by the athletic association. The income from
alumni, faculty and students' athletic fees was only slightly more
than $8,100 and the total expenses
nearly $16,000. Track, baseball
and crew were the heaviest losers,
while football under the S. A. T.
C. regime was the only sport to
show a credit. The minor sports
helped to make up the deficit.
New Penn Club in New York.

The New York Alumni of Penn
have just purchased a nine-story
building at 11 to 17 East 45th
street for a club. This site, just
off Fifth Avenue, is one of the
finest in the clubhouse district,
and the building itself, formerly
considered one of the best apartment houses in the city, is excellently suited for the purpose of
the Club, containing every improvement, in addition to smoking, lounging and billiard rooms.

LA R G E.

In the recent dual meet with
Harvard, a new world's record for
the 200-yard swimming relay race
was established by the Yale swimming team, which covered the distance in the remarkable time of
1 minute, and 39 and 4-5 seconds.
The team won the meet by the
score of 48 to 5, and clipped a
second from the previous record
of 1 minute, and 40 and 4-5 seconds. The new record was established by the team which created
the former record on February 13,
composed of the following men:
J. M. Hincks,of Bridgeport,Conn.;
L. Thurston, of Honolulu; E. Binney, of Sound Beach, Conn., and
R. F. Solly, of New York City.
The girls at Milwaukee Normal
School are taking an active interest in the science of "Leap-Year
Proposals." They have leaped to
the leap - year opportunity en
masse, and their study of "how
to pop" may change the course of
many lives. Boys, beware!

HOWARD AND LEXINGTON

Collegiate Swimming Association Holds
Second Meeting at Hopkins' Club.

The Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association, which was organized recently, held its second
meeting on April 17, at the Hopkins Club. The meeting was attended by J. C. Riley, of Rutgers;
Farington, of Lehigh, and B. Russell Murphy, Theodore Gould and
D. Rowland, of Hopkins. At
present, only four colleges—Lehigh, Rutgers, Catholic University
and Johns Hopkins—have ratified
the constitution. It is expected,
however, that Stevens, Swarthmore and Haverford will join the
association before the end of the
week.
At the meeting of April 17, the
by-laws were drawn up, modeled
after those of the Inter-Collegiate
Swimming Association. The officers of the association and executive committee were elected. The
officers are: J. C. Riley, of Rutgers, president; Charles V. Moran, of Catholic University, vicepresident; Theodore Gould, of
Hopkins, secretary; Farington, of
Lehigh, treasurer. The executive
committee is composed of the four
men just mentioned and Prof. H.
R. Reiter, of Lehigh; B. Russell
Murphy, of Hopkins; Mehrhoff, of
Rutgers, and Bruhuer, of Catholic
University. Tentative plans have
been made for the first swimming
meet, to take place in one of the
eastern cities next fall.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 20, 1920.

IJAS. SCHOULER LECTURESHIP1
In March, 1908, Dr. James
Schouler, of Boston, who had lectured in this University annually
since 1891, announced his purpose
to found a permanent lectureship
in the University, to be known as
"The James Schouler Lectureship
in History and Political Science."
The -donor expressed that wish
that "such lectures be given annually, if possible, . . . and that
persons of promise or prominence
be selected to lecture, who are
capable of interesting, as well as
instructing, an audience."
The ninth course on the Schouler Foundation will be delivered
by Paul Samuel Reinsch, Ph. D.,
LL. D., scholar and diplomat,
sometime United States Minister
to China, who will give five lectures on "The Development of Nationalism and Representative Government in China."
The lectures will be given in the
hall of the Civil Engineering
Building at Homewood, beginning
Tuesday, April 20, 1920, at 4.15
o'clock. Entrance to the grounds
at Charles and Thirty-second
streets.
